channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Boris Johnson Agrees to Resign as Prime Minister
item.description: After the latest in a series of scandals prompted a rebellion by members of his Conservative Party, Mr. Johnson said he would step down. He plans to remain as prime minister until a successor is chosen.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Russian Strikes in Donetsk Are Just a Prelude to Coming Assault, Analysts Say
item.description: At least seven civilians were killed in the last 24 hours by Russian attacks in the Donbas region in the east, Ukrainian officials said on Thursday, as Putin’s forces lay the groundwork for an onslaught.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Planned Resignation, Explained
item.description: Britain’s prime minister said he would step down, less than three years after a landslide election victory. Here’s a guide to why he was forced out and who might succeed him.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Peter Robins

item.title: Brittney Griner Pleads Guilty to Drug Charges in Russian Court
item.description: “There was no intent,” the American basketball star told a Russian judge, as any resolution of the highly politicized case appeared to shift toward the diplomatic arena.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Tania Ganguli
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted to a courtroom outside Moscow for her hearing on Thursday, carrying photos of her wife.

item.title: Deadly Glacier Collapse in Italy Shows Reach of Europe’s New Heat
item.description: A collapse at the top of one of Italy’s tallest peaks offered the latest evidence of the deadly threat posed by rising temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The area of the Marmolada glacier where a section broke off, killing at least nine people.

item.title: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies, if They’re Married
item.description: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials have been doling out tax and housing credits, educational benefits and cash to encourage women to have more children. But a marriage prerequisite is increasingly unappealing to those who prefer to parent alone.

item.title: To Pick Johnson’s Successor, Britain’s Conservatives Have to Reinvent the Party
item.description: The choice of Britain’s next prime minister falls to the governing Conservatives, whose lawmakers pushed Boris Johnson to resign and now have to reinvent their party without him.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announcing his resignation at Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: For Foreign Fighters in Ukraine, a War Unlike Any They’ve Seen
item.description: Small groups of Western combat veterans are on the front lines, but many more with fewer skills are left trying to find a role to play.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Valerie Hopkins and Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighters in Ukraine’s Odin Unit, made up of Ukrainians and foreign volunteers including Britons and Americans, during an operation in March in Irpin.

item.title: For Boris Johnson, a Chaotic Reign Ends With a Chaotic Exit
item.description: The risk-taking bravado of Britain’s colorful prime minister was not enough to compensate for his shortcomings, or overcome a catastrophic loss of party support.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: “I want to tell you how sorry I am to be giving up the best job in the world,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in the statement announcing his departure, adding: “Them’s the breaks.”

item.title: Mass Funeral Deepens Mystery: Why Did 21 South African Teens Die in Tavern?
item.description: Survivors of the tragedy last month recounted in interviews the presence of a mysterious gas and then a crush to escape. Officials say the stampede didn’t kill them.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Zipo-zenkosi Ncokazi
item.media:description: Residents wept after laying flowers at the entrance to Enyobeni Tavern in East London, South Africa, where 21 teenagers died in the early hours of June 26.

item.title: 12 Members of a Religious Group Charged in Death of 8-Year-Old
item.description: Elizabeth Struhs of Queensland, Australia, died in January because, according to the police, she was denied medical care.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Elizabeth Struhs in an undated photo provided to The Times by her sister, Jayde Struhs, left.

item.title: China Seeks to Pre-Empt Sanctions in Case of Taiwan Clash, F.B.I. Chief Says
item.description: Looking ahead to a possible conflict, Beijing wants to shield itself from the kind of economic penalties levied against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the F.B.I. director says.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-tank fortifications from previous conflicts line the shore in Kinmen, an island group held by Taiwan, with mainland China in the background.

item.title: A Year After President’s Murder, Haitians Keep Waiting to Hit Rock Bottom
item.description: In the year since President Jovenel Moïse was killed, the country’s despair has deepened. Gangs now vie with the government for control.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The empty streets of Port-au-Prince one morning last August.

item.title: Ethnic Killings in Ethiopia Add to Crisis
item.description: Allegations of a second recent ethnic massacre in the restive region of Oromia further destabilize a country already coping with civil war in a northern region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A World Food Program truck carrying grain burned last month while en route to Tigray, in northern Ethiopia, the site of a devastating civil war that started nearly two years ago.

item.title: Boris Johnson Quits Amid Latest Scandal, a Messy End to a Messy Tenure
item.description: In a dizzying two days, Conservative Party lawmakers who had defended the prime minister through crises turned against him, and now some are vying to replace him despite harsh economic headwinds.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announcing his resignation at Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Boris Johnson Plans to Resign
item.description: Also, Brittney Griner pleads guilty to Russian drug charges and Beijing has a new Covid strategy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announcing his resignation outside 10 Downing Street on Thursday in London.

item.title: Rotterdam Won’t Dismantle Bridge to Allow Jeff Bezos’ Superyacht Through
item.description: The Dutch city faced an uproar as it considered dismantling a section of a 95-year-old bridge. Now the boat’s builder has decided not to apply for a permit.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Candidates to Replace Boris Johnson Reflect a More Diverse Conservative Party
item.description: Among those expected to vie for the prime ministership are a son of Indian immigrants, an Iraqi refugee, a son of a Pakistani bus driver, and several women.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Jessica Taylor/UK Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s cabinet — which included several women and ethnic minorities — was the most ethnically diverse in Britain’s modern memory.

item.title: Boris Johnson Leaves Behind Fraught Economy and Uneasy Brexit Legacy
item.description: Britain is in the grips of a cost-of-living crisis, and the departure of its prime minister leaves uncertainty about the government’s next moves.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks lining up at the Channel Tunnel terminal in December 2020.

item.title: Fin Whales Are Making a Comeback in Antarctic Waters, a Study Finds
item.description: Once hunted to the brink of extinction, fin whales in the Southern Ocean have rebounded and returned to their historic feeding grounds, according to a new survey.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin

item.title: Norwegian Cruises will drop its requirement for negative coronavirus tests in most countries, but not in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Norwegian Cruise Line has a global fleet of 28 ships.

item.title: Read Boris Johnson’s Resignation Speech
item.description: “I want you to know how sad I am to be giving up the best job in the world,” the British prime minister said in announcing that he was stepping down. “But them’s the breaks.”
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson prepares to make a statement outside 10 Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: What Finally Pushed Boris Johnson to Resign?
item.description: Despite everything stacked against him, Mr. Johnson did not go quietly.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson at a cabinet meeting on Tuesday at Downing Street in London.

item.title: Bangladesh Sees Jump in Covid Cases Before Eid Celebrations
item.description: The average number of new cases has risen to the highest since February, signaling a new wave. The country’s health system nearly collapsed in August.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Bangaldesh reported 1,728 Covid cases on Wednesday, more than 40 times the number of cases recorded just a month ago.

item.title: Kazuki Takahashi, Yu-Gi-Oh! Creator, Dies at 60
item.description: The manga artist won international fame with a story that inspired a trading card game rivaling Pokemon as one of Japan’s most recognizable cultural exports.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Kazuki Takahashi in 2005. Mr. Takahashi began working as a manga artist in the early 1980s

item.title: ‘This is Ukraine!’ The national flag is raised on Snake Island, officials say, in a symbol of Kyiv’s defiance of Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A satellite image from Maxar Technologies showed smoke rising from Snake Island last month.

item.title: Boris Johnson Agrees to Resign. What Happens Next?
item.description: After the latest in a series of scandals prompted a rebellion by members of his Conservative Party, Boris Johnson said he would step down. Now what?
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Londoners React to the Boris Johnson News
item.description: In the capital, many Britons expressed a sense of relief after learning that the prime minister’s days were numbered.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A protest against Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Conservative Party in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Internal Inconsistencies
item.description: The people who claim widespread election fraud have made little effort to put together a logical argument.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene with her “Stop the Steal” face mask in 2021.

item.title: Who Will Succeed Boris Johnson as Prime Minister?
item.description: A small group is stepping to center stage as Britain’s political crisis intensifies, including the rival Boris Johnson beat last time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Beijing Introduces Local Vaccine Pass and Urges Older People to Get Shots
item.description: The city announced the change months after other countries had put vaccine passports in place.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The subway on Wednesday in Beijing, where people will soon need to be vaccinated to enter public places like libraries.

item.title: California Shows Why Fossil Fuels Are So Hard to Quit
item.description: Dozens of state and local budgets depend heavily on tax revenue from oil, gas and coal to fund schools, hospitals and more. Replacing that money is turning out to be a major challenge in the fight against climate change.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Alisha Jucevic
item.media:description: Fred Holmes, the chairman of a small oil company who also runs a scholarship foundation, at his home in Taft, Calif.

item.title: The Pincher scandal is only the latest in a long line of controversies for Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson speaking at Downing Street in May after the release of the Sue Gray report.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Boris Johnson’s crumbling support.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: A top Russian official threatens the U.S. with the ‘wrath of God’ over war crime investigations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Dmitri Medvedev, a leading Russian politician and close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, at a meeting outside Moscow in January.

item.title: Food insecurity and hunger afflicted 2.3 billion people in 2021, and the war will add more, the U.N. says.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain bins storing corn, wheat, sunflower and soybeans, in Boryspil, Ukraine, outside of the country’s capital, in May.

item.title: Boris Johnson Vows to Go On Amid Wave of Cabinet Resignations
item.description: A wave of resignations — more than 50 by Thursday — and calls for him to step down showed the prime minister’s support within his Conservative Party melting away, but he remained defiant.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson leaving No. 10 Downing Street for Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: With infections surging, Cyprus reinstates an indoor mask mandate.
item.description: The mandate will be enforced with spot inspections and fines of up to 300 euros ($305) for violators.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A shopping district in central Nicosia, Cyprus, in January.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: War Displaces Millions of Ukrainians
item.description: Also, Boris Johnson battles to keep his job and Europe labels gas and nuclear energy “green.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the frontline of the war in Ukraine has moved, many who fled have returned home. But for those from the country’s east, the prospect of returning has only become more uncertain and remote.

item.title: France Will Renationalize EDF
item.description: The state already has a majority stake in France’s main electricity and nuclear company. The move reflected President Emmanuel Macron’s desire to champion economic and energy sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Tricastin nuclear power plant in the commune of Saint-Paul-Trois-Châteaux, in France’s Drôme region, in June.

item.title: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
item.description: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the frontline of the war has moved, many Ukrainians who have fled have returned home. But for those from the country’s east, the prospect of returning has grown only more uncertain.

item.title: As Russia cuts gas shipments, Europe moves to bail out energy providers.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy, Stanley Reed, Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Uniper, which runs this gas storage facility in Bavaria, could get financial relief from Germany’s Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Germany Set to Allow Bailout of Uniper, Its Largest Natural Gas Importer
item.description: Berlin and Paris are preparing bailouts as Europe braces for further cuts to gas supplies next week and economists warn of a recession.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Uniper, which runs this gas storage facility in Bavaria, could get financial relief from Germany’s Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Johnson follows a familiar playbook in his response to the latest scandal.
item.description: The British prime minister’s blueprint for dealing with a crisis, his critics say, almost never begins, and rarely ends, with simply telling the truth.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Jessica Taylor/UK Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaking in the House of Commons on Wednesday.

item.title: A team of Ukrainian medics navigates life and death on the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: ‘The Daily’ podcast looks at Brittney Griner’s detention in Russia.
Sajid Javid Addresses Parliament After Calls for Johnson’s Resignation
item.description: In explaining to Parliament why he stepped down from Boris Johnson’s government, Mr. Javid said, “Treading the tightrope between loyalty and integrity has become impossible in recent months.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Sajid Javid, Britain’s former health secretary, speaking in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: The battlefields of eastern Ukraine are largely abandoned fields and streets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents surveying damage caused by shelling in a bazaar in Sloviansk, eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Three War Scenarios
item.description: And what will influence the outcome in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident among destroyed stores in Sloviansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Europe Calls Gas and Nuclear Energy ‘Green’
item.description: Critics say the decision is likely to reverberate beyond Europe’s borders and hamper its efforts to lead the global climate negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A nuclear power station in Civaux, France. European officials argue that gas and nuclear power are important in helping the continent move away from more damaging energy sources.

item.title: Nadhim Zahawi, the newly appointed chancellor, affirms his support for the prime minister.
item.description: Mr. Zahawi, Britain’s new top finance minister, defended Boris Johnson on Wednesday’s morning news shows, but said that his focus was on tackling inflation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Nadhim Zahawi is Britain’s fourth chancellor of the Exchequer in three years.

item.title: Who Has Resigned So Far in Boris Johnson’s Government
item.description: A growing number of officials in Boris Johnson’s government are stepping down, adding to the pressure on the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Tess Felder
item.media:description: Will Quince, right, then a candidate in Colchester, with Mr. Johnson and Priti Patel, who is now home secretary, in 2019.

item.title: How One Restaurateur Transformed America’s Energy Industry
item.description: Charif Souki’s longshot bet on liquid natural gas, or L.N.G., paid off handsomely — and turned the United States into a leading fossil-fuel exporter.
item.dc:creator: Jake Bittle
item.media:credit: Sebastian Nevols for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charif Souki in London in June.

item.title: The Best Books to Take You Through Berlin, Germany
item.description: The German author Daniel Kehlmann, most recently of the novel “Tyll,” recommends books that explore the city’s painful past and dynamic present.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Kehlmann
